summary: This document is a series of internal emails from July 23, 2019, regarding an incident at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with red marks on his neck. The emails discuss the incident, his medical and psychological assessments, and plans for his housing, including a request for information about his cell mate.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate at the center of the incident, found with red marks on his neck in his cell, placed on suicide watch, and who alleged his cell mate attempted to kill him.

persons.name: Psychologist

persons.context: Recipient of emails regarding the Epstein incident, based at MCC New York.

connections.description: The Operations Lieutenant was the first responder who found Epstein in his cell and initiated the incident response.
The Physician Assistant medically assessed Epstein following the cell incident.
The Psychologist evaluated Epstein's mental state and decided to keep him on suicide watch.
The Associate Warden was being briefed on and managing the housing and status of inmate Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Injuries in Cell
events.description: At 1:27 a.m., staff responded to Epstein's cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). He was found lying on the floor with red marks on his neck, was unresponsive initially, and was placed in restraints and on suicide watch. He alleged his cell mate attempted to kill him.

events.title: Epstein's Medical and Psychological Assessments
events.description: Epstein was medically assessed at 6:30 a.m. (noting a circular line of erythema on his neck) and psychologically evaluated at 9:10 a.m., resulting in his continued placement on suicide watch.

events.title: Internal Email Chain Regarding Epstein's Status
events.description: A series of emails between prison officials discusses the confusing incident memo, requests a clearer summary for higher authorities (BOP Director), and plans to review Epstein's case for placement in the general population with an appropriate cell mate.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, 150 Park Row, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with red marks on his neck and alleged his cell mate had attempted to kill him.
Epstein was placed on suicide watch following the incident, but a medical assessment hours later found him smiling, in no apparent distress, and unable or unwilling to explain the marks.
Prison officials were actively reviewing his case for placement in the general population and seeking an appropriate cell mate at the time of the emails.
There was internal confusion about the incident report, prompting a request for a clearer summary to be sent to the BOP Director.
The document highlights security and monitoring concerns regarding Epstein's welfare in custody prior to his death.
